proof_markdown:
Proof. Set $\mathcal Y_*:=\mathrm{LS}^{\mathrm{restr}}_{\check G,*}$ and $\mathcal C_*:=Shv_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(\operatorname{Bun}_{G,*})$ for $*\in\{K,k\}$. For $\mathcal F\in QCoh(\mathcal Y_*)$, let $H_{\mathcal F,*}$ denote the endofunctor of $\mathcal C_*$ defined by the $QCoh(\mathcal Y_*)$-action, and let $\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},*}\in\mathcal C_*$ be the Poincaré !$-vacuum. Define the continuous, $QCoh(\mathcal Y_*)$-linear coevaluation
$$
\mathrm{coev}_*:QCoh(\mathcal Y_*)\to\mathcal C_*,\qquad \mathcal F\mapsto H_{\mathcal F,*}(\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},*}).
$$
By definition, the coarse right adjoint $\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse},*}:\mathcal C_*\to QCoh(\mathcal Y_*)$ is the continuous right adjoint to $\mathrm{coev}_*$. We must show that the natural transformation
$$
\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{QCoh}}_{K\to k}\circ \mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse},K}\;\xRightarrow{\;\simeq\;}\;\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse},k}\circ \mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}
$$
is an isomorphism.

Step 1 (specialization commutes with coevaluation). The specialization functor $\mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}:\mathcal C_K\to\mathcal C_k$ is $QCoh(\mathcal Y_k)$-linear with respect to the monoidal base-change functor $\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{QCoh}}_{K\to k}:QCoh(\mathcal Y_K)\to QCoh(\mathcal Y_k)$; i.e., for all $\mathcal F\in QCoh(\mathcal Y_K)$ and $\mathcal C\in\mathcal C_K$ there is a canonical isomorphism
$$
\mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}\big(H_{\mathcal F,K}(\mathcal C)\big)\;\xRightarrow{\;\simeq\;}
H_{\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{QCoh}}_{K\to k}(\mathcal F),k}\big(\mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}(\mathcal C)\big).
$$
Moreover, $\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},R_0}$ is ULA over $\operatorname{Spec}R_0$, hence $\mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}(\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},K})\simeq\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},k}$. Evaluating the above isomorphism at $\mathcal C=\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},K}$ yields a natural isomorphism, functorial in $\mathcal F$,
$$
\alpha:\;\mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}\circ\mathrm{coev}_K\xRightarrow{\;\simeq\;}
\mathrm{coev}_k\circ \mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{QCoh}}_{K\to k}.
$$

Step 2 (passage to right adjoints). Since $\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse},*}\dashv\mathrm{coev}_*$ for $*\in\{K,k\}$, the mates (Beck–Chevalley) correspondence in the 2-category of cocomplete DG categories with continuous functors associates to $\alpha$ a natural transformation between the right adjoints
$$
\alpha^R:\;\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{QCoh}}_{K\to k}\circ \mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse},K}\Longrightarrow \mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse},k}\circ \mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}.
$$
Taking mates preserves invertibility, hence $\alpha^R$ is an isomorphism. This is precisely the asserted canonical commutativity of the square. ∎

statement: Flatness and ULA of parabolic Zastava kernels over families. With $j:\\operatorname{Bun}_{P^-,R_0}\\hookrightarrow \\operatorname{Bun}^{\\,\\mathrm{g}}_{P^-,R_0}$, the object $j_!(\\boldsymbol e)$ over $\\operatorname{eq}_-$ is $R_0$-flat in the sense that for any $\\mathcal F\\in \\mathrm{Shv}(\\operatorname{Bun}_{M,R_0})$ that is ULA over $R_0$, the convolution kernel defining $\\mathrm{Eis}^-_{!}(\\mathcal F)$ remains ULA over $R_0$ and its formation commutes with base change to $K$ and $k$.
proof_markdown:
\begin{proof}
Let $S:=\Spec(R_0)$. Denote by $g:=\operatorname{eq}_-:\operatorname{Bun}^{\,\mathrm g}_{P^-,S}\to \operatorname{Bun}_{M,S}$ and by $\overline p: \operatorname{Bun}^{\,\mathrm g}_{P^-,S}\to \operatorname{Bun}_{G,S}$ the natural (proper) projection. By Theorem 4.4.5, the kernel
$$
\mathcal K\ :=\ j_!(\boldsymbol e)\ \in \mathrm{Shv}\bigl(\operatorname{Bun}^{\,\mathrm g}_{P^-,S}\bigr)
$$
is ULA with respect to $g$.

We will use two standard facts about ULA and vanishing cycles (for sheaf theories admitting the six functors and vanishing cycles; the statements extend from schemes to Artin stacks locally of finite type by smooth descent from atlases):

(1) Stability under proper pushforward and base change: If $h:Y\to Z$ is proper over $S$ and $\mathcal A\in\mathrm{Shv}(Y)$ is ULA over $S$, then $h_!\mathcal A$ is ULA over $S$, and for any $S'\to S$ one has canonical base change $(h_!\mathcal A)|_{Z_{S'}}\simeq h'_{\,!}(\mathcal A|_{Y_{S'}})$.

(2) ULA-pull–tensor over a base (vanishing cycles calculus): Let $g:Y\to X$ be an $S$-morphism of finite type between Artin stacks, $\mathcal K\in\mathrm{Shv}(Y)$ be ULA with respect to $g$, and $\mathcal F\in\mathrm{Shv}(X)$ be ULA over $S$. Then the object
$$
\mathcal A\ :=\ g^{\,!}\mathcal F\ \overset{!}{\otimes}\ \mathcal K\ \in\mathrm{Shv}(Y)
$$
is ULA over $S$. Moreover, for every base change $S'\to S$ there is a canonical isomorphism
$$
\mathcal A|_{Y_{S'}}\ \simeq\ g'^{\,!}(\mathcal F|_{X_{S'}})\ \overset{!}{\otimes}\ \mathcal K|_{Y_{S'}}.
$$

For (2) one may test ULA on strict Henselian traits $T\to S$. Writing $X_T=X\times_S T$, $Y_T=Y\times_S T$ and $s\in T$ the closed point, universal local acyclicity of $\mathcal K$ with respect to $g$ identifies the vanishing cycles by the canonical isomorphism (SGA7, Exp. XIII, Prop. 2.1.13 and Cor. 2.1.14):
$$
\phi_{Y_T/T}\bigl(g_T^{\,!}(\mathcal F_T)\overset{!}{\otimes}\mathcal K_T\bigr)
\ \simeq\ g_s^{\,!}\bigl(\phi_{X_T/T}(\mathcal F_T)\bigr)\ \overset{!}{\otimes}\ i^*\mathcal K_T.
$$
Since $\mathcal F$ is ULA over $S$, $\phi_{X_T/T}(\mathcal F_T)=0$, hence $\phi_{Y_T/T}(\mathcal A_T)=0$ for all $T\to S$, i.e. $\mathcal A$ is ULA over $S$. The base-change identification follows from the same formalism (loc. cit.).

Now let $\mathcal F\in\mathrm{Shv}(\operatorname{Bun}_{M,S})$ be ULA over $S$. Apply (2) to $g=\operatorname{eq}_-$ and $\mathcal K=j_!(\boldsymbol e)$:
$$
\mathcal A\ :=\ g^{\,!}\mathcal F\ \overset{!}{\otimes}\ j_!(\boldsymbol e)
$$
is ULA over $S$, and for all $S'\to S$ there is a canonical base-change isomorphism
$$
\mathcal A|_{\operatorname{Bun}^{\,\mathrm g}_{P^-,S'}}\ \simeq\ g'^{\,!}(\mathcal F|_{\operatorname{Bun}_{M,S'}})\ \overset{!}{\otimes}\ j'_!(\boldsymbol e).
$$
Next, $\overline p$ is proper (Drinfeld's compactification), hence by (1),
$$
\Eis^-_{!,S}(\mathcal F)\ :=\ \overline p_!\bigl(\mathcal A\bigr)[\text{standard shift/twist}]
$$
is ULA over $S$, and for any $S'\to S$ one has canonical base change
$$
\Eis^-_{!,S}(\mathcal F)\big|_{\operatorname{Bun}_{G,S'}}\ \simeq\ \overline p'_{\,!}\Bigl(g'^{\,!}(\mathcal F|_{\operatorname{Bun}_{M,S'}})\ \overset{!}{\otimes}\ j'_!(\boldsymbol e)\Bigr)[\text{same shift/twist}]
\ =\ \Eis^-_{!,S'}(\mathcal F|_{\operatorname{Bun}_{M,S'}}).
$$
Taking $S'=\Spec(K)$ and $S'=\Spec(k)$ gives the asserted compatibility with base change to $K$ and $k$.

Therefore, for every $\mathcal F$ that is ULA over $R_0$, the convolution kernel $g^{\,!}\mathcal F\otimes j_!(\boldsymbol e)$ is ULA over $R_0$, and $\Eis^-_{!,R_0}(\mathcal F)$ is ULA over $R_0$ with formation commuting with base change to $K$ and $k$. This is exactly the stated $R_0$-flatness of $j_!(\boldsymbol e)$ over $\operatorname{eq}_-$.\qedhere
\end{proof}

statement:
For any standard parabolic P^- with Levi M and any \(\mathcal F\in \mathrm{Shv}_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(\operatorname{Bun}_{M,K})\), there is a canonical isomorphism
\[ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{G,k}\Bigl(\mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}\,\mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}\bigl(\mathcal F\bigr)\Bigr)\ \simeq\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{M,k}\Bigl(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star\mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}(\mathcal F)\Bigr), \]
compatible with Hecke and with translation by \(\rho_P(\omega_X)\).
proof_markdown:
**Proof.** Fix the cohomological integer
$$
\delta:=\delta\bigl(N^-_P\bigr)_{\rho_P(\omega_X)}
$$
and adopt the normalization
$$
\mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}\ :=\ \bigl(\mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}\bigr)_{\mathrm{raw}}[\delta],
$$
so that its right adjoint $\mathrm{CT}^-_!$ is unshifted. With this convention, all adjunctions below are cohomologically unshifted.

Step 1 (specialization, Hecke, translation). Specialization commutes with parabolic Eisenstein and with Hecke functors, and is $t$-exact (Theorem 3.1.6(D,E), Proposition 4.2.5):
$$
\mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}\circ \mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}\ \simeq\ \mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}\circ \mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k},\qquad
H_{V,k}\circ \mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}\ \simeq\ \mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}\circ H_{V,K}.
$$
Translation by $\rho_P(\omega_X)$ is defined over $R_0$, hence commutes with specialization and Hecke.

Step 2 (comparison over $R_0$ and construction of $\Theta_{R_0}$). Working over the base $R_0$, for $\mathcal F\in \mathrm{Shv}_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(\operatorname{Bun}_{M,R_0})$, the diagonal-kernel formalism (Theorem 5.1.3) and the definition of the Whittaker coefficient give
$$
\mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{G,R_0}\bigl(\mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}(\mathcal F)\bigr)
\ \simeq\ \operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Bun}_{G,R_0}}\bigl(\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},G,R_0},\ \mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}(\mathcal F)\bigr).
$$
Using the adjunction $\mathrm{Eis}^-_!\dashv\mathrm{CT}^-_!$ in our normalization,
$$
\operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Bun}_{G,R_0}}\bigl(\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},G,R_0},\ \mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}(\mathcal F)\bigr)
\ \simeq\ \operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Bun}_{M,R_0}}\Bigl((\mathrm{transl}_{\rho_P(\omega_X)})^*\!\bigl(\mathrm{CT}^-_!(\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},G,R_0})\bigr),\ \mathcal F\Bigr).
$$
By Theorem 7.4.6 there is a canonical isomorphism in $\mathrm{Shv}(\operatorname{Bun}_{M,R_0})$
$$
(\mathrm{transl}_{\rho_P(\omega_X)})^*\!\bigl(\mathrm{CT}^-_!(\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},G,R_0})\bigr)[d]\ \simeq\ \mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star \mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},M,R_0},
$$
where $d$ is the integer from GLC3, Corollary 10.1.8. Therefore
$$
\operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Bun}_{M,R_0}}\Bigl((\mathrm{transl}_{\rho_P(\omega_X)})^*\!\bigl(\mathrm{CT}^-_!(\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},G,R_0})\bigr),\ \mathcal F\Bigr)
\ \simeq\ \operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Bun}_{M,R_0}}\Bigl(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star \mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},M,R_0}[-d],\ \mathcal F\Bigr).
$$
Using the Hecke action and the diagonal pairing (Theorem 5.1.3),
$$
\operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Bun}_{M,R_0}}\Bigl(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star \mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},M,R_0}[-d],\ \mathcal F\Bigr)
\ \simeq\ \operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Bun}_{M,R_0}}\Bigl(\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},M,R_0},\ \mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star \mathcal F\Bigr)[d]
\ =\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{M,R_0}\bigl(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star \mathcal F\bigr)[d].
$$
Altogether, we obtain a canonical natural transformation of functors over $R_0$:
$$
\Theta_{R_0}:
\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{G,R_0}\circ \mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}
\ \xrightarrow{\ \sim\ }\ 
\bigl(\mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{M,R_0}\circ(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star(-))\bigr)[d].
$$

Step 3 (Hecke-compatibility). For $W\in\operatorname{Rep}(\check M)^{\otimes I}$, let $H^M_W$ be the global Hecke functor on $\mathrm{Shv}(\operatorname{Bun}_{M,R_0})$. Set
$$
K_L:=(\mathrm{transl}_{\rho_P(\omega_X)})^*\!\bigl(\mathrm{CT}^-_!(\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},G,R_0})\bigr),\quad K_R:=\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star \mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},M,R_0}.
$$
By Theorems 4.2.2, 4.4.5, and 5.1.3, convolution with global Satake objects commutes with the pull–push operations defining $\mathrm{CT}^-_!$, $\mathrm{Eis}^-_!$, and the diagonal pairing; hence the canonical map of Theorem 7.4.6 is $\operatorname{Rep}(\check M)$-equivariant. Applying $\operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Bun}_{M,R_0}}(-,\mathcal F)$ and the standard compatibilities of Hecke with Hom yields commutative squares intertwining $H^M_W$. Compatibility with $\mathrm{transl}_{\rho_P(\omega_X)}$ is tautological from the definition of $K_L$.

Step 4 (identification of the shift $d$). Restrict $\Theta_{R_0}$ to the generic fiber $K$. We get
$$
\Theta_{K}:
\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{G,K}\circ \mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}
\ \xrightarrow{\ \sim\ }\ 
\bigl(\mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{M,K}\circ(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star(-))\bigr)[d].
$$
Evaluate $\Theta_K$ at $\mathcal F=\mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},M,K}$. Set
$$
V_K\ :=\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{M,K}\bigl(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star \mathrm{Poinc}^{!}_{\mathrm{Vac},M,K}\bigr).
$$
By the diagonal-kernel formalism (Theorem 5.1.3) and the fact that $\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})$ is the factorization algebra corresponding to the Chevalley–Eilenberg cochains $C^\bullet(\check{\mathfrak n}^-_P)$, the complex $V_K$ identifies with the underlying cochain complex of $C^\bullet(\check{\mathfrak n}^-_P)$. In particular, $V_K$ is cohomologically nonnegatively graded and $H^0(V_K)\simeq K$ (the unit of the $E_\infty$-algebra).

On the other hand, $\Theta_K$ gives an isomorphism $V_K\xrightarrow{\sim} V_K[d]$. Since $H^i(V_K)=0$ for $i<0$ and $H^0(V_K)\neq 0$, an isomorphism $V_K\simeq V_K[d]$ forces $d=0$. Hence the natural transformation $\Theta_{R_0}$ is already unshifted:
$$
\Theta_{R_0}:
\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{G,R_0}\circ \mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}
\ \xrightarrow{\ \sim\ }\ 
\mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{M,R_0}\circ(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star(-)).
$$
It is compatible with Hecke and with $\mathrm{transl}_{\rho_P(\omega_X)}$ by Step 3.

Step 5 (passage to fibers and specialization). By base change along $\operatorname{Spec}R_0\to\operatorname{Spec}K,\operatorname{Spec}k$ and ULA of all ingredients (Theorems 4.2.2, 4.4.2, 4.4.5, 5.1.3), $\Theta_{R_0}$ specializes to canonical Hecke-compatible isomorphisms
$$
\Theta_K:\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{G,K}\circ \mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}\ \xrightarrow{\ \sim\ }\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{M,K}\circ(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star(-)),
$$
$$
\Theta_k:\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{G,k}\circ \mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}\ \xrightarrow{\ \sim\ }\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{M,k}\circ(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star(-)).
$$
Finally, for any $\mathcal F\in \mathrm{Shv}_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(\operatorname{Bun}_{M,K})$, using Step 1 and Proposition 4.2.5,
$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{G,k}\Bigl(\mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}\,\mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}(\mathcal F)\Bigr)
&\ \simeq\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{G,k}\Bigl(\mathrm{Eis}^-_{!,\,\rho_P(\omega_X)}\,\mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}(\mathcal F)\Bigr)\\
&\ \xrightarrow{\ \Theta_k\ }\ \mathrm{coeff}^{\mathrm{Vac}}_{M,k}\Bigl(\mathrm{Fact}(\Omega_{\mathrm{loc}})\star \mathrm{Sp}_{K\to k}(\mathcal F)\Bigr),
\end{aligned}
$$
which is compatible with Hecke and with translation by $\rho_P(\omega_X)$. This is the asserted specialization-compatible Eisenstein–Whittaker comparison in families.

$\square$

statement: For $\mathcal F\in\mathrm{Shv}_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(\mathrm{Bun}_G)_{\mathrm{temp}}$, the scheme-theoretic support satisfies $\mathrm{Supp}_{\check G}\bigl(\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(\mathcal F)\bigr)=\mathrm{Supp}_{\check G}\bigl(\mathrm{QCoh}(\mathrm{LS}^{\mathrm{restr}}_{\check G})\text{-module generated by the }\mathrm{Hecke}_{\mathrm{fact}}(G)\text{-orbit of }\mathcal F\bigr)$. In particular, $f\in\Gamma(\mathrm{LS}^{\mathrm{restr}}_{\check G},\mathcal O)$ acts nilpotently on the Hecke orbit of $\mathcal F\iff f|_{\mathrm{Supp}_{\check G}(\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(\mathcal F))}=0$.
proof_markdown:
\begin{proof}
Set $Y:=\mathrm{LS}^{\mathrm{restr}}_{\check G}$, $\Gamma:=\Gamma(Y,\mathcal O_Y)$, and $\mathcal C:=\mathrm{Shv}_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(\operatorname{Bun}_G)_{\mathrm{temp}}$. Fix $\mathcal F\in\mathcal C$. By the restricted Langlands equivalence (Main Theorem 1.3.9), there exists a union of connected components $i: Y'\hookrightarrow Y$ and a $\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)$-linear, Hecke-compatible equivalence
\[
\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_G:
\mathrm{Shv}_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(\operatorname{Bun}_G)\xrightarrow{\sim}\operatorname{IndCoh}_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(Y').
\]
By Theorem 1.1.10 there is a $\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)$-linear adjunction
\[
\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr},L}_{G,\mathrm{temp}}:
\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)\rightleftarrows\mathcal C:\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}},
\]
which, after transporting along $\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_G$, identifies with the adjunction $\Upsilon_{Y'}\dashv\Xi_{Y'}$ between $\operatorname{IndCoh}(Y')$ and $\mathrm{QCoh}(Y')$, where the $\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)$-action on $\operatorname{IndCoh}(Y')$ is through $i^*:\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)\to\mathrm{QCoh}(Y')$. Let $j:Y''\hookrightarrow Y$ denote the complementary open-and-closed embedding so that $Y\simeq Y'\sqcup Y''$ and
$$
\mathcal O_Y\;\simeq\;i_*\mathcal O_{Y'}\oplus j_*\mathcal O_{Y''}
$$
as $\mathcal O_Y$-algebras.

Let
\[
\mathcal E:=\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_G(\mathcal F)\in\operatorname{IndCoh}_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(Y'),\qquad
\mathcal L:=\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(\mathcal F)\in\mathrm{QCoh}(Y).
\]
Under the transport described above, one has a canonical identification
\begin{equation}\label{eq:coarse-iXi}
\mathcal L\;\simeq\;i_*\,\Xi_{Y'}(\mathcal E)\in\mathrm{QCoh}(Y).
\end{equation}
For $V\in\operatorname{Rep}(\check G)$, Hecke-compatibility gives $\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(H_V(-))\simeq V_Y\otimes\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(-)$.

We compare supports via annihilator ideal sheaves. For any $\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)$-linear presentable stable category $\mathcal D$ and $X\in\mathcal D$, define the quasi-coherent ideal sheaf
\[
\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(X):=\ker\bigl(\mathcal O_Y\longrightarrow\underline{\mathrm{End}}_{\mathcal D}(X)\bigr)\subset\mathcal O_Y.
\]
For a $\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)$-linear full subcategory $\mathcal M\subset\mathcal D$ stable under colimits and direct summands, set
\[
\mathcal I(\mathcal M):=\bigcap_{X\in\mathcal M}\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(X)\subset\mathcal O_Y.
\]
The (scheme-theoretic) support of $X$ (resp. of $\mathcal M$) is the closed substack of $Y$ cut out by $\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(X)$ (resp. by $\mathcal I(\mathcal M)$).

Let $\mathcal M_{\mathcal F}\subset\mathcal C$ be the smallest $\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)$-module subcategory, closed under colimits and direct summands, containing all Hecke translates $\{H_V(\mathcal F)\}_V$.

\medskip\noindent\textbf{Step 1: Hecke invariance of the sheafified annihilator.}

(1a) For any $V\in\operatorname{Rep}(\check G)$ and $X\in\mathcal C$,
\[
\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}\bigl(H_V(X)\bigr)=\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(X).
\]
Indeed, $H_V$ is $\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)$-linear and biadjoint to $H_{V^\vee}$, and the identity is a retract of $H_{V^\vee}\circ H_V$ via coevaluation/evaluation. If $a\in\mathcal O_Y$ kills $X$, $a$ kills $H_V(X)$ by linearity. Conversely, if $a$ kills $H_V(X)$, then $a$ kills $H_{V^\vee}H_V(X)$, hence also its retract $X$.

(1b) If $P\in\operatorname{Perf}(Y)$ and $X\in\mathcal C$, then
\[
\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(P\otimes X)=\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(X),
\]
by dualizability of $P$ and the same retract argument.

Consequently,
\[
\mathcal I(\mathcal M_{\mathcal F})=\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(\mathcal F).
\]

\medskip\noindent\textbf{Step 2: Passage to the spectral side and comparison with the coarse transform.}

Transporting along the $\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)$-linear equivalence $\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_G$ and using that the $\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)$-action on $\operatorname{{IndCoh}}(Y')$ factors through $i^*$, the map $\mathcal O_Y\to\underline{\mathrm{End}}_{\mathcal C}(\mathcal F)$ decomposes through $\mathcal O_Y\simeq i_*\mathcal O_{Y'}\oplus j_*\mathcal O_{Y''}$ with $j_*\mathcal O_{Y''}$ acting by $0$. Hence
\begin{equation}\label{eq:ann-on-Y-via-Yprime}
\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(\mathcal F)=j_*\mathcal O_{Y''}\;\oplus\;i_*\bigl(\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_{Y'}}(\mathcal E)\bigr)\subset\mathcal O_Y.
\end{equation}
Similarly, using \eqref{eq:coarse-iXi},
\begin{equation}\label{eq:ann-coarse-on-Y}
\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(\mathcal L)=j_*\mathcal O_{Y''}\;\oplus\;i_*\bigl(\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_{Y'}}(\Xi_{Y'}(\mathcal E))\bigr).
\end{equation}
Therefore, to compare $\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(\mathcal F)$ with $\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(\mathcal L)$, it suffices to show
\begin{equation}\label{eq:sheaf-ann}
\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_{Y'}}(\mathcal E)=\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_{Y'}}\bigl(\Xi_{Y'}(\mathcal E)\bigr).
\end{equation}

This is Zariski-local on $Y'$. Let $U\to Y'$ be affine with $U$ an affine scheme, and write $\Xi_U$ for the pullback of $\Xi_{Y'}$. Then both $\operatorname{IndCoh}(U)$ and $\mathrm{QCoh}(U)$ are presentable, left-complete, with compatible $t$-structures, and $\Xi_U$ restricts to a $\mathrm{QCoh}(U)$-linear $t$-exact equivalence on bounded-below parts with inverse $\Upsilon_U$. For $f\in\Gamma(U,\mathcal O_U)$, the endomorphism $\phi:=f\cdot\mathrm{id}$ is $t$-exact, and for any $X$ one has
\[
\phi_X=0\iff \forall n\ge 0:\;\phi_{\tau^{\ge -n}X}=0
\]
by left-completeness. Applying this to $X=\mathcal E|_U$ and transporting along the bounded-below equivalence yields
\[
\operatorname{Ann}^{(0)}_{\Gamma(U,\mathcal O_U)}(\mathcal E|_U)=\operatorname{Ann}^{(0)}_{\Gamma(U,\mathcal O_U)}\bigl(\Xi_U(\mathcal E|_U)\bigr).
\]
Since quasi-coherent ideal subsheaves of $\mathcal O_U$ are determined by global sections on affine $U$, the equality above implies
\[
\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_U}(\mathcal E|_U)=\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_U}\bigl(\Xi_U(\mathcal E|_U)\bigr).
\]
These equalities glue over $Y'$, establishing \eqref{eq:sheaf-ann}. Plugging this into \eqref{eq:ann-on-Y-via-Yprime} and \eqref{eq:ann-coarse-on-Y} gives
\[
\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(\mathcal F)=\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(\mathcal L).
\]

\medskip\noindent\textbf{Step 3: Equality of scheme-theoretic supports.}

By Step 1, $\mathcal I(\mathcal M_{\mathcal F})=\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(\mathcal F)$. By Step 2,
\[
\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(\mathcal F)=\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}\bigl(\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(\mathcal F)\bigr).
\]
Therefore the closed substacks of $Y$ cut out by these two ideal sheaves coincide, i.e.
\[
\mathrm{Supp}_{\check G}\bigl(\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(\mathcal F)\bigr)
=\mathrm{Supp}_{\check G}\Bigl(\text{the }\mathrm{QCoh}(Y)\text{-module subcategory generated by the }\mathrm{Hecke}_{\mathrm{fact}}(G)\text{-orbit of }\mathcal F\Bigr).
\]

\medskip\noindent\textbf{Step 4: The “in particular.”}

Let $f\in\Gamma(Y,\mathcal O_Y)$. For an affine morphism $U\to Y$, the condition “$f$ acts nilpotently on the $\mathrm{Hecke}_{\mathrm{fact}}(G)$-orbit of $\mathcal F$ after restriction to $U$” is equivalent to $f|_U\in\sqrt{\mathcal I(\mathcal M_{\mathcal F})|_U}$ (the affine criterion for nilpotent action on a $\mathrm{QCoh}(U)$-linear subcategory). Using $\mathcal I(\mathcal M_{\mathcal F})=\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_Y}(\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(\mathcal F))$ and the standard affine identity
\[
\bigl(f|_{\mathrm{Supp}(\mathcal L|_U)}=0\bigr)\iff f|_U\in\sqrt{\operatorname{Ann}^{(0)}_{\Gamma(U,\mathcal O_U)}(\mathcal L|_U)}\iff f|_U\in\sqrt{\operatorname{Ann}_{\mathcal O_U}(\mathcal L|_U)}
\]
(for $\mathcal L:=\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(\mathcal F)$), we obtain
\[
\text{$f$ acts nilpotently on the Hecke orbit of $\mathcal F$}\iff f\big|_{\mathrm{Supp}_{\check G}(\mathsf L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(\mathcal F))}=0.
\]
Both sides are Zariski-local on $Y$, hence the equivalence holds globally.

This proves the stated equality of scheme-theoretic supports and the “in particular.”
\qed
\end{proof}

statement: Conservativity of the coarse functor on tempered objects. The functor $L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}: Shv_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(Bun_G)\to QCoh(LS^{\mathrm{restr}}_{\check G})$ is conservative on the full subcategory of tempered objects: if $\mathcal F\in Shv_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(Bun_G)_{\mathrm{temp}}$ and $L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(\mathcal F)\simeq 0$, then $\mathcal F\simeq 0$. More generally, for a morphism $f: \mathcal F\to \mathcal F'$ between tempered objects, if $L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}(\mathrm{Cone}(f))\simeq 0$ then $f$ is an isomorphism.
proof_markdown:
Proof. Let $Y:=LS^{\mathrm{restr}}_{\check G}$ and write $L:=L^{\mathrm{restr}}_{G,\mathrm{coarse}}$.

Conservativity on tempered objects. Let $\mathcal F\in Shv_{\mathrm{Nilp}}(Bun_G)_{\mathrm{temp}}$ with $L(\mathcal F)\simeq 0$. By the support-control statement for tempered objects,
$$
\mathrm{Supp}_{\check G}\bigl(L(\mathcal F)\bigr)
= \mathrm{Supp}_{\check G}\Bigl(\text{the $QCoh(Y)$-module generated by the Hecke}_{\mathrm{fact}}(G)\text{-orbit of }\mathcal F\Bigr).
$$
Since $L(\mathcal F)\simeq 0$, the left-hand side is empty, so every global function $f\in\Gamma(Y,\mathcal O_Y)$ acts nilpotently on the Hecke-orbit of $\mathcal F$. Taking $f=1$, the identity Hecke functor (coming from the trivial representation) acts nilpotently; in particular $\mathrm{id}_{\mathcal F}$ is nilpotent. But $\mathrm{id}_{\mathcal F}^2=\mathrm{id}_{\mathcal F}$, hence $\mathrm{id}_{\mathcal F}=0$, so $\mathcal F\simeq 0$.

Detection of isomorphisms via cones. Let $f:\mathcal F\to\mathcal F'$ be a morphism between tempered objects. The tempered subcategory is stable under cones, so $\mathrm{Cone}(f)$ is tempered. If $L(\mathrm{Cone}(f))\simeq 0$, the previous paragraph gives $\mathrm{Cone}(f)\simeq 0$, hence $f$ is an isomorphism. $\square$

statement:
Spectral specialization at the QCoh-valued (coarse Langlands) level. For any $\cF\in\Shv_{\Nilp}(\Bun_{G,K})_{\temp}$, under the identification in Conjecture A there is a canonical isomorphism in $\QCoh(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k})$:
$$
\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k,\coarse}\bigl(\Sp_{K\to k}(\cF)\bigr)
\;\simeq\;
\omega\otimes^{\mathbb L}\underline{\operatorname{Hom}}\bigl(\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac,\spec,k},\,\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}\,\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,K}(\cF)\bigr),
$$
compatible with Hecke and Eisenstein. In particular, applying global sections recovers the Whittaker coefficient identity
$$
\coeff^{\Vac}_{G,k}\bigl(\Sp_{K\to k}(\cF)\bigr)\;\simeq\;\Gamma\Bigl(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k},\,\omega\otimes^{\mathbb L}\underline{\operatorname{Hom}}\bigl(\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac,\spec,k},\,\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}\,\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,K}(\cF)\bigr)\Bigr),
$$
with the same compatibilities.
proof_markdown:
Fix a DVR $R_0$ with fraction field $K$ and residue field $k$. By the restricted Langlands equivalence (Main Theorem 1.3.9), for $s\in\{K,k\}$ there is an equivalence
$$
\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,s}:
\Shv_{\Nilp}(\Bun_{G,s})\xrightarrow{\ \sim\ }\IndCoh_{\Nilp}(,'\!\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,s}),
$$
compatible with the ambient embeddings; write $\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac,\spec,s}:=\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,s}(\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac,s})$ and $\omega$ for the dualizing sheaf on $\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,s}$.

1) Whittaker normalization at the QCoh level. By the Whittaker normalization (Gaitsgory–Raskin, §1.4.6), there is a canonical identification of $\QCoh(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,s})$-valued functors
$$
\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,s,\coarse}(-)\;\simeq\;\omega\otimes^{\mathbb L}\underline{\Hom}\bigl(\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac,\spec,s},\,\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,s}(-)\bigr).
$$

2) Apply $s=k$ to $\Sp_{K\to k}(\cF)$. Using step 1 with $s=k$ gives a canonical identification in $\QCoh(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k})$:
$$
\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k,\coarse}\bigl(\Sp_{K\to k}(\cF)\bigr)
\;\simeq\;
\omega\otimes^{\mathbb L}\underline{\Hom}\bigl(\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac,\spec,k},\,\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k}(\Sp_{K\to k}(\cF))\bigr).
$$

3) Spectral specialization (Conjecture A). Conjecture A provides a canonical identification, functorial and $\QCoh$-linear on tempered objects,
$$
\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k}\circ\Sp_{K\to k}
\;\simeq\;
\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}\circ\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,K}.
$$
Substituting this into the right-hand side of step 2 yields the desired isomorphism in $\QCoh(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k})$:
$$
\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k,\coarse}\bigl(\Sp_{K\to k}(\cF)\bigr)
\;\simeq\;
\omega\otimes^{\mathbb L}\underline{\Hom}\bigl(\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac,\spec,k},\,\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}\,\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,K}(\cF)\bigr).
$$

Taking global sections of both sides and using step 1 again (together with Serre duality if desired) recovers the stated identity for Whittaker coefficients. 

Hecke and Eisenstein compatibilities follow from the functorial compatibilities of the ingredients:
- $\Sp_{K\to k}$ commutes with Hecke (Theorem 4.2.2) and with parabolic Eisenstein (Theorem 3.1.6), and preserves temperedness (Proposition 4.5.2).
- $\mathsf L^{\restr}_G$ is compatible with Hecke/Satake and intertwines automorphic and spectral Eisenstein (Theorem 1.4.6).
- The identification in Conjecture A is $\QCoh$-linear and compatible with these structures.
- The formation $\omega\otimes^{\mathbb L}\underline{\Hom}(-,-)$ is $\QCoh$-linear, hence preserves Hecke and Eisenstein compatibilities.
Therefore the resulting isomorphism is canonical and compatible with Hecke and Eisenstein, as required. ∎

statement:
In mixed characteristic (char(K)=0, char(k)=p>0), the spectral specialization functor $$
\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}:
\IndCoh_{\Nilp}(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,K})\longrightarrow\IndCoh_{\Nilp}(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k})
$$ is essentially surjective. Equivalently, every object of $\IndCoh_{\Nilp}(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k})$ is the specialization of an object over $K$ with nilpotent singular support.
proof_markdown:
**Proof.**

Fix a DVR $R_0$ with fraction field $K$ of characteristic $0$ and residue field $k$ of characteristic $p>0$.

1) Equivalences on the generic and special fibers. By Main Theorem 1.3.9, the restricted Langlands functor induces canonical equivalences
$$
\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,K}:
\Shv_{\Nilp}(\Bun_{G,K})\xrightarrow{\ \sim\ }\IndCoh_{\Nilp}(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,K}),
\qquad
\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k}:
\Shv_{\Nilp}(\Bun_{G,k})\xrightarrow{\ \sim\ }\IndCoh_{\Nilp}(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k}).
$$
These are $\QCoh(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,(-)})$-linear.

2) Definition of the spectral specialization. Let
$$
\Sp_{K\to k}:\Shv_{\Nilp}(\Bun_{G,K})\longrightarrow\Shv_{\Nilp}(\Bun_{G,k})
$$
be the specialization functor from Theorem 3.1.6; in particular, it is a Verdier quotient (hence essentially surjective), $t$-exact, intertwines the $\QCoh(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k})$-action, commutes with Hecke functors and parabolic Eisenstein, and the square with the coarse functor $\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,\coarse}$ and $\Sp^{\QCoh}_{K\to k}$ canonically commutes.

Transporting along the above equivalences, define the spectral specialization
$$
\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}
\;:=\;
\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k}\circ\Sp_{K\to k}\circ(\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,K})^{-1}
:\IndCoh_{\Nilp}(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,K})\longrightarrow\IndCoh_{\Nilp}(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k}).
$$
By construction, $\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}$ is $\QCoh(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k})$-linear, commutes with global Hecke functors and with spectral Eisenstein, and is compatible with the coarse functors in the sense that
$$
\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,\coarse}\circ (\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k})^{-1}\circ\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}
\;\simeq\;
\Sp^{\QCoh}_{K\to k}\circ\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,\coarse}\circ (\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,K})^{-1}.
$$

3) Essential surjectivity. Since $\Sp_{K\to k}$ is essentially surjective (Theorem 3.1.6) and $\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,(-)}$ are equivalences, their conjugate $\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}$ is essentially surjective. Explicitly, for any $\cF_k\in\IndCoh_{\Nilp}(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k})$, pick $\cC_k\in\Shv_{\Nilp}(\Bun_{G,k})$ with $\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k}(\cC_k)\simeq\cF_k$. Choose $\cC_K\in\Shv_{\Nilp}(\Bun_{G,K})$ such that $\Sp_{K\to k}(\cC_K)\simeq\cC_k$. Then
$$
\cF_K\;:=\;\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,K}(\cC_K)\in\IndCoh_{\Nilp}(\LS^{\restr}_{\breve G,K})
\quad\text{satisfies}\quad
\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}(\cF_K)\;\simeq\;\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k}(\Sp_{K\to k}(\cC_K))\;\simeq\;\mathsf L^{\restr}_{G,k}(\cC_k)\;\simeq\;\cF_k.
$$
Thus every object on the special fiber is the specialization of an object on the generic fiber with nilpotent singular support. ∎

statement:
For any $E\in\IndCoh\big(\rLS^{\restr}_{\breve G,K}\big)$ one has an equality of closed derived substacks inside $\rLS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k}$:
$$
\Supp_{\breve G}\big(\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}(E)\big)
=\overline{\Spc}_{K\to k}\big(\Supp_{\breve G}(E)\big),
$$
where $\overline{\Spc}_{K\to k}$ denotes schematic specialization of closed subsets under the base-change $\rLS^{\restr}_{\breve G,K}\to\rLS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k}$.
proof_markdown:
Set $Y_{R_0}:=\rLS^{\restr}_{\breve G,R_0}$ with generic and special fibers $Y_K$ and $Y_k$, and write
$$j: Y_K\hookrightarrow Y_{R_0},\qquad i: Y_k\hookrightarrow Y_{R_0}$$
for the canonical open and closed immersions. Let $E\in\IndCoh(Y_K)$.

Define spectral specialization along the trait by the functor
$$
\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}:
\IndCoh(Y_K)\xrightarrow{\ j_{*,\mathrm{ren}}\ }\IndCoh(Y_{R_0})\xrightarrow{\ i^*\ }\IndCoh(Y_k),
\qquad \Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}:=i^*\circ j_{*,\mathrm{ren}}.
$$
Here $j^*:\IndCoh(Y_{R_0})\to\IndCoh(Y_K)$ is a localization with fully faithful right adjoint $j_{*,\mathrm{ren}}$, and $i_*:\IndCoh(Y_k)\to\IndCoh(Y_{R_0})$ is fully faithful with both adjoints $i^*$ and $i^!$.

We compute supports using two standard facts for $\IndCoh$.

(A) Closure under renormalized extension by zero. For any open immersion $j:U\hookrightarrow Y$ and $\cM\in\IndCoh(U)$,
$$
\Supp_Y\big(j_{*,\mathrm{ren}}\cM\big)=\overline{\Supp_U(\cM)}\subset Y.
$$
Indeed, support is Zariski-local on $Y$. For a quasi-compact open $W\subset Y$, with $U_W:=U\times_Y W$ and $j_W:U_W\hookrightarrow W$, one has
$$
\big(j_{*,\mathrm{ren}}\cM\big)\big|_W\;\simeq\;(j_W)_*\big(\cM\big|_{U_W}\big),
$$
where $j_W$ is quasi-compact and the usual $(j_W)_*$ exists; for such $j_W$ the familiar formula $\Supp_W\big((j_W)_*\cN\big)=\overline{\Supp_{U_W}(\cN)}$ holds. Gluing over $W$ gives the claim.

(B) Intersection under $*$-pullback to a closed substack. For a closed immersion $i:Z\hookrightarrow Y$ and $\cN\in\IndCoh(Y)$,
$$
\Supp_Z\big(i^*\cN\big)=\Supp_Y(\cN)\times_Y Z.
$$
This follows because $i_*:\IndCoh(Z)\xrightarrow{\sim}\IndCoh_Z(Y)$ is an equivalence onto the full subcategory of objects scheme-theoretically supported on $Z$, and $i^*$ is left adjoint to $i_*$. Under this identification, $i^*$ extracts the maximal quotient of $\cN$ scheme-theoretically supported on $Z$, hence its support is the scheme-theoretic intersection with $Z$.

Apply (A) to $j:Y_K\hookrightarrow Y_{R_0}$ and $E$, and then (B) to $i:Y_k\hookrightarrow Y_{R_0}$ and $j_{*,\mathrm{ren}}E$:
$$
\begin{aligned}
\Supp_{Y_k}\big(\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}(E)\big)
&=\Supp_{Y_k}\big(i^*\,j_{*,\mathrm{ren}}E\big)\\
&=\Supp_{Y_{R_0}}\big(j_{*,\mathrm{ren}}E\big)\times_{Y_{R_0}} Y_k\\
&=\overline{\Supp_{Y_K}(E)}\times_{Y_{R_0}} Y_k.
\end{aligned}
$$
By definition, $\overline{\Supp_{Y_K}(E)}\times_{Y_{R_0}} Y_k$ is the schematic specialization $\overline{\Spc}_{K\to k}\big(\Supp_{Y_K}(E)\big)$ of the closed derived substack $\Supp_{Y_K}(E)\subset Y_K$ along $Y_{R_0}\to\Spec R_0$. This identifies
$$
\Supp_{\breve G}\big(\Sp^{\IndCoh}_{K\to k}(E)\big)
=\overline{\Spc}_{K\to k}\big(\Supp_{\breve G}(E)\big)
$$
as closed derived substacks of $\rLS^{\restr}_{\breve G,k}$. ∎

statement:
For $k= F_q$ and any closed union of connected components $'LS^{estr}_{ reve G}	humbsupsubsetLS^{estr}_{ reve G}$, the inclusion $IndCoh_{Nilp}('LS^{estr}_{ reve G})	oIndCoh('LS^{estr}_{ reve G})$ induces an isomorphism on categorical Frobenius traces. Consequently, for any compact $ F\
in\u000a\rShv_{\rNilp}(\bun_G)$ one has $\Tr(\Frob,\,\sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse}(\fF))=\Tr(\Frob,\,\sL^{\restr}_G(\fF))$ in the sense of Grothendieck–Lefschetz on stacks.
proof_markdown:
**Proof.** Let $k=\FF_q$, set $Y:=\rLS^{\restr}_{\breve G}$, and let $i:\,'\!Y\hookrightarrow Y$ be a closed union of connected components (hence open-and-closed).

Step 1 (categorical trace stability for a closed union of components). Because $i$ is open-and-closed, there are canonical Frobenius–equivariant decompositions of DG categories
$$
\rIndCoh(Y)\;\simeq\;\rIndCoh(\,'\!Y)\oplus\rIndCoh(Y\smallsetminus\,'\!Y),\qquad
\rIndCoh_{\rNilp}(Y)\;\simeq\;\rIndCoh_{\rNilp}(\,'\!Y)\oplus\rIndCoh_{\rNilp}(Y\smallsetminus\,'\!Y).
$$
By Theorem 1.5.2 the inclusion $\rIndCoh_{\rNilp}(Y)\hookrightarrow\rIndCoh(Y)$ induces an isomorphism on categorical Frobenius traces. The categorical trace is additive with respect to direct sums of DG categories, hence the induced map on each direct summand is an isomorphism. Therefore,
$$
\Tr\!\left(\Frob,\,\rIndCoh_{\rNilp}(\,'\!Y)\right)\xrightarrow{\ \sim\ }\Tr\!\left(\Frob,\,\rIndCoh(\,'\!Y)\right).
$$

Step 2 (coarse vs. refined spectral images on global sections, via temperization). Let $\cF\in\rShv_{\rNilp}(\bun_G)$ be compact and set $E:=\sL^{\restr}_G(\cF)\in\rIndCoh_{\rNilp}(Y)$. Consider the $\rQCoh(Y)$-action on $\rShv(\bun_G)$ and the functor
$$
\operatorname{act}_Y:\ \rQCoh(Y)\longrightarrow \rShv(\bun_G)_{\temp},\qquad M\longmapsto M\cdot\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac},
$$
which is Frobenius–equivariant and continuous. Let $u^R:\ \rShv(\bun_G)\to\rShv(\bun_G)_{\temp}$ be the right adjoint to the inclusion $\rShv(\bun_G)_{\temp}\hookrightarrow\rShv(\bun_G)$.

The coarse right adjoint on the tempered subcategory, $\sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse,\temp}:\rShv(\bun_G)_{\temp}\to\rQCoh(Y)$, is (by definition) right adjoint to $\operatorname{act}_Y$. We extend it to $\rShv_{\rNilp}(\bun_G)$ by
$$
\sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse}(\cF)\ :=\ \sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse,\temp}\big(u^R\cF\big).
$$
Then for $\cF\in\rShv_{\rNilp}(\bun_G)$ we have canonically and Frobenius–equivariantly
$$
\begin{aligned}
\RGamma\big(Y,\,\sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse}(\cF)\big)
&=\RHom_{\rQCoh(Y)}\!\big(\cO_Y,\,\sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse,\temp}(u^R\cF)\big)\\
&\simeq\RHom_{\rShv(\bun_G)_{\temp}}\!\big(\operatorname{act}_Y(\cO_Y),\,u^R\cF\big)\qquad(\operatorname{act}_Y\dashv\sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse,\temp})\\
&\simeq\RHom_{\rShv(\bun_G)}\!\big(\operatorname{act}_Y(\cO_Y),\,\cF\big)\qquad\text{(by the adjunction of inclusion $\dashv\,u^R$)}\\
&=\RHom_{\rShv(\bun_G)}\!\big(\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac},\,\cF\big).\tag{2.3')
\end{aligned}
$$

By Main Theorem 1.3.9 there exists a union of components $Y_0\subset Y$ such that
$$
\sL^{\restr}_G:\ \rShv_{\rNilp}(\bun_G)\xrightarrow{\ \sim\ }\rIndCoh_{\rNilp}(Y_0)
$$
is an equivalence, compatible with the embedding into $\rIndCoh_{\rNilp}(Y)$. Moreover, $\sL^{\restr}_G(\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac})\simeq\Xi\cO_{Y_0}$. Hence
$$
\begin{aligned}
\RHom_{\rShv(\bun_G)}\!\big(\Poinc^{!}_{\Vac},\,\cF\big)
&\simeq\RHom_{\rIndCoh(Y_0)}\!\big(\Xi\cO_{Y_0},\,E|_{Y_0}\big)\\
&\simeq\RHom_{\rIndCoh(Y)}\!\big(\Xi\cO_Y,\,E\big),\tag{2.4}
\end{aligned}
$$
where the last step uses that $E$ is supported on $Y_0$. Finally, by the adjunction $\Psi\dashv\Xi$,
$$
\RGamma\big(Y,\,\Psi(E)\big)\;\simeq\;\RHom_{\rIndCoh(Y)}\!\big(\Xi\cO_Y,\,E\big).\tag{2.1}
$$
Combining (2.3'), (2.4), and (2.1) yields a canonical Frobenius–equivariant isomorphism
$$
\RGamma\big(Y,\,\sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse}(\cF)\big)\;\simeq\;\RGamma\big(Y,\,\Psi(\sL^{\restr}_G(\cF))\big).
$$
Taking alternating traces of $\Frob$ gives
$$
\Tr\!\left(\Frob,\,\sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse}(\cF)\right)
\;=\;\Tr\!\left(\Frob,\,\sL^{\restr}_G(\cF)\right),
$$
where the right-hand side is understood as the Grothendieck–Lefschetz trace on $\RGamma\big(Y,\Psi(\sL^{\restr}_G(\cF))\big)$. By Theorem 1.1.10, $\sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse}$ sends compact objects to eventually coconnective ones, so the Grothendieck–Lefschetz traces on stacks are defined; the displayed identification shows both sides are simultaneously defined and equal.

Combining Steps 1 and 2 proves the Frobenius-trace stability for any closed union of components and the stated equality for $\sL^{\restr}_{G,\coarse}$ versus $\sL^{\restr}_G$. ∎
